Author: mdc.tf
Content: Yeah, DayZ doesn't use a traditional database like A2/A3 did (usually SQL, sometimes Redis). Basically DayZ serializes every piece of data that needs to be saved, and it has to be unserialized in exactly the right order; so if - for example - a low level mod like CF inserted something into OnStoreLoad/Save on ItemBase, and you have another mod that does the same, if CF *removes* that piece of data from their instance of OSS/OSL, everything's out of step by 1 in the serialization.
